Organic Nanomaterials Lab Department of Chemistry Hannam University Daejeon 34054 Republic of Korea Remarkable attention has been directed to Prussian blue (PB) and its analogues (PBA) as one of the most widely used metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) especially in the field of energy storage devices due to their fabulous features such as 3D open framework, high surface area, controllable distribution of pores and the low cost. Nevertheless, their depressed conductivity causes some insulation when being used as an electrode for supercapacitors leading to be restricted in further applications particularly the electronics. To the best of our knowledge, our review aimed primarily to give a total picture of the research that was done on utilizing PB and PBA for fabricating the electrodes of supercapacitor, studying their synthesis approaches in addition to the hybridization with other materials such as graphene, CNTs and conducting polymer. It also addresses the transformation of PB or PBA into other interesting nanostructures such as oxides, sulfides, and bicomponent of graphitic carbon nitride/metal oxides, as well. Furthermore, It exhibits various avenues for overcoming their disadvantages of bad cycle life, retention rate and not achieving the desired values of energy/power densities opening the door for enlarging the number of researches on their application as supercapacitors. Graphical abstract According to the superb features of PB or PBA, we overviewed their synthesis designs and the utilization as electrodes for supercapacitors. For overcoming their drawbacks, this review suggests the key points for improving their electrochemical performance in the field of energy storage. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal hexacyanoferrates Supercapacitors Electrolyte Energy density Cyclic stability 1 Introduction Nowadays, the energy and environment pollution dilemmas are considered as serious cases in our life that can attract a continuous interest in developing new energy storage electrodes such as fuel cells, supercapacitors, and rechargeable batteries. These systems are used to store the electric energy for operating hybrid electric vehicles, smart grids and electronic devices [1–4]. Specifically, lithium ion-containing batteries have been shown as a representative class for the family of energy storage devices with a superior energy density. Even though, they reveal the tortures of low power density conduction and inferior cycle life. Meanwhile, supercapacitors (SCs) are utilized to cure the disadvantages of batteries such as maintaining the high energy rate and cycling stability for conducting the required current to the electric vehicles, computers and so on. Also, they can give a power density output of hundreds to thousands of times with respect to the batteries. Unfortunately, they failed to store much lower charge from 3 to 30 times. Thus, supercapacitors are specified for fields that can be adhered to power blasts. Interestingly, Supercapacitors could be hybridized with battery-based electrodes to obtain the power and energy demands, longer cycle life and enlarge the application of supercapacitors. As can be seen from Fig. 1 , compared to other energy storage devices such as electrolytic capacitors which have a higher power density value than supercapacitors (only 10 kW/kg). However, they can attain several order of magnitude recorded for the energy density in relation to the capacitors one [2]. Additionally, these electrodes can occupy the space found between batteries and aluminum capacitors because they could store a huge quantity of energy. The relationship between the power density (X-axes) and the energy density (Y) is known as the Ragone plot and can be also utilized to display the discharge time as represented by the diagonal lines where E = P × t and is shown in Fig. 1 for the different current storage technologies. Regrettably, other important parameters such as cycle life and cost needed for the full understanding of the supercapacitance performance cannot be described by the Ragone plot [5,6]. As depicted from Fig. 2 that supercapacitors can be categorized mostly into three different electrodes which are pseudocapacitors, electric double-layer capacitors (EDLCs), and hybrid capacitors [8]. The pseudocapacitors can be worked by the reversible redox reactions between the electrode and electrolyte. They can differentially undergo by three types of redox mechanisms; underpotential deposition, redox pseudocapacitance such as RuO2·nH2O, and intercalation pseudocapacitance. The process of underpotential deposition can be found when the adsorption of metal ions happens as a monolayer on the surface of another metal substrate at a potential higher than their redox voltage such as lead on the surface of a gold electrode. While redox pseudocapacitance takes place when a faradic charge transfer is raised from the electrochemical adsorption of ions onto the surface or near the surface of a material. Differentially, the intercalation pseudocapacitance involves the intercalation of ions into the pseudocapacitance material ducts or layers leading to redox chemical reaction without changing their crystallinity [3]. The EDLCs can sore the electrical energy electrostatically. Besides, the hybrid capacitors are designed by the hybridization between non-redox electrodes (carbon) and the redox electrodes (conducting polymer or metal oxide) to get the superior capacitance performance of both capacitor and battery-based electrodes leading to the high stability against cycling with the low cost compared to that of EDLCs. It can be categorized into three kinds; asymmetrical, composite and battery type electrodes [9,10]. Asymmetric supercapacitors have been developed and commonly utilized in a spacious scale of device configurations to address the low energy density dilemma for supercapacitors. While undergoing charge and discharge reactions, these devices can expand the applied potential window obtained from the two working electrodes based cells. It is well known that the maximum potential obtained in an aqueous electrolyte for symmetric devices is up to ~1.2 V, whilst the applied potential for asymmetric supercapacitor can be enlarged beyond 2.0 V [11,12]. Whereas, the composite hybrids reveal a synergistic effect between carbon (EDLCs) and metal oxide (redox materials) to obtain both outstanding properties of them such as high conductivity, capacitance, and long cycle life. This is because the carbon nanostructure with the high surface area can form a fast road for the charge transfer in addition to the high energy density and specific capacitance of the metal oxides due to their redox reactions. On the other hand, the function of the battery-type hybrids is to increase the Ragone plot̕ s midway corresponded to the great rise in energy and power densities by creating faradic nanoparticles with fast electroactive reaction with the electrolyte. There are important factors that can evaluate the supercapacitor's efficiency such as specific capacitance, operating potential, specific power and energy density besides cycle stability [13,14]. Additionally, the ability to store energy is found to be related promptly to the nature of the electrode material. Thus, the development of electrodes with excellent conductivity and stable effectiveness is considered from the most interesting research areas [15–17]. Based on the mechanism of energy storage, various nanomaterials have been commonly used as electrodes for supercapacitors application such as carbon-based materials, conducting polymers and metal oxides [4]. Metal organic frameworks are principally considered novel porous crystalline nanomaterials with suburb properties of high surface area, ability to carry other guest molecules and structural tailorability [18–20]. The fabrication of MOFs involves a reaction of metal cations or their clusters with the organic linkers. The wise control of these two components can give features with desired applications such as sensors, catalysis, and electronic applications [21]. Prussian blue (PB) and its derivatives (PBA) are known as one of the oldest and precious MOFs that can be used as electrode materials for supercapacitors because of their excellent electrochemical features aside from their fast charge and discharge that coming from the outstanding structure [22,23]. Besides their fabulous chemical structure containing metal and organic constituents, PB can be transformed into other interesting nanostructures by the calcination in various atmospheres such as nitrogen and air. They can also act as sacrificial agents to prepare metal derivatives such as oxides, sulfides, and phosphides or bicomponent of graphitic carbon nitride /metal oxides. Moreover, the 3-D network morphology of PB can catalyze the incorporation and intercalation of other ions into its structure. Consequently, PB and its derivatives can show excellent electrochemical efficiency as electrode materials. To the best of our knowledge, our review aimed to give for the first time an up to date specific and thorough overview for applying PB and its derivatives in the field of supercapacitors. The outstanding properties of PB on the electrochemical efficiency are also investigated. The recent progress to mend the capacitance and cyclic stability of PB and their derivatives is highlighted by displaying the postulated strategies of their combination with graphene, conducting polymers and so on. To the end, this review could increase the challenges in the forthcoming time to develop new PB nanocomposites and their derivatives as supercapacitor materials. 2 Charge storage mechanisms 2.1 EDLCs EDLCs are the most feasible and commercially utilized supercapacitors. The concept of EDLCs can be displayed in Fig. 3 when the immersion of an electrode in an ionic electrolyte is happened and leads to acquiring a spontaneous double layer from ordering the charges at the interface between the electrode surface and electrolyte. The double layer of different charges takes a time of ~10−8 to be formed which is shorter than that is spent for the redox reactions of pseudocapacitance (10−2 − 10−4 s) [24]. The physical electrostatic adsorption is responsible for storing the charge at the interface surfaces. Meanwhile, the charge storage doesn't include any transfer of charge (redox reaction) between the surface of electrodes and electrolytes. As a result, the electrode specific capacitance is robustly based on the exposed area and the surface features of the carbon-based electrode [25–27]. A general equation used to calculate the capacitance of EDLCs based electrode is shown in the following equation. (1) c = ∈ r ∈ 0 d A , where ∈ r is refers to the electrolyte relative permittivity, ∈ 0 is the vacuum permittivity, A is the electrode surface area and d is the separation distance between the electrical double layers. The thickness of the debye layer is found to be from 5 to 10 Å and can be affected by different parameters such as the solvation shell, the electrolytes concentration and their ions size [26]. The specific capacitance for carbon-based electrodes is in the range 10–21 µF/cm2 and is controlled by the electrolyte permittivity, surface area and the operative electrical double layer capacitance [6,29]. By changing the surface area of the used carbon material in the fabrication of electrode from 1000 to 3000 m2/g, the gravimetric capacitance was increased from 300 to 550 F/g [30]. Nevertheless, the reported value from the experimental study is almost 100−250 F/g because of the incomplete activity of the sites on the electrode surface to undergo the electrochemical reaction and the limited conductivity [25]. Consequently, all carbon-based supercapacitors presented in the market can store only a little energy from 3 to 10 Wh/kg. Various carbon materials have been used as EDLCs electrodes such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, porous carbon and activated carbon [31–34]. 2.2 Pseudocapacitors Pseudocapacitance is another type of charge storage mechanism that strongly depends on the rapid redox reversible substrates or nearby-substrate faradic reactions (See Fig. 3). The ideal electrical behavior of pseudocapacitors is similar to that of ELDCs as the current function varies constantly against the voltage values resulted in obtaining a proportional constant that is defined as capacitance [5]. Additionally, the materials that can undergo the redox reactions can be extrinsic or intrinsic. The intrinsic case means that the redox behavior for the material can appear with the different particle sizes and morphologies, but the extrinsic material shows the faradic mechanism only under specified particle size diameter and mainly cannot be observed for the bulky material. From the kinetic mechanism, the electroanalytical processes in the pseudocapacitance are found to be different from the battery based materials and can be limited by the surface controlled reactions compared to the battery electrodes (diffusion reactions) [35]. It is pertinent to note that pseudocapacitor electrodes can store the charge with various mechanisms based on the used material for fabricating the electrode such as metal oxide faradic reactions, electrochemical doping and dedoping of conducting polymers, intercalated pseudocapacitance and underpotential deposition [36]. As it was aforementioned that the combination of an electrical double layer with the redox mechanism together could improve the gravimetrical capacitance of the electrode. The calculated capacitance of redox electrodes could be larger than that obtained from EDLCs with about 10‒100 times. Nevertheless, the power density is commonly down compared to EDLCs because of the delayed behavior of faradic reactions. In addition to that, the materials of the pseudocapacitance electrode were found to undergoes shrinkage and swellability while doing charge and discharge cycle reactions giving rise to the bad mechanical and cycle life stability [37,38]. 3 Structural characteristics of PB and PBA PB was historically known as the premier discovered synthetic pigment and was found by the researcher “Dippel” in Berlin with the name of “Caeruleum Berolinense”. It was primarily fabricated from potash, alum (KAl(SO4)2) and iron sulfate during the extraction process of cochineal [39] by giving a blue color precipitate. The preparation method of PB was firstly presented by John Woodward. Recently, Prussian blue has been applicably reported as an efficient hydrogen storage nanomaterials [40] Besides being used as biosensors for the determination of glucose, l-cysteine and so on due to their susceptible for the reaction with hydrogen peroxide and hydroxyl radicals [41,42]. This is in addition to the utilization in cancer therapy because they can absorb and convert the light of laser into heat [43] and in the water treatment to eliminate cesium ions [44]. The porous framework structure of PB could also be used as energy storage devices. Due to the considerable features of PB and PBA, Fig. 4 is representing a rapid growth on the researches done by using PB and PBA in many fields especially as supercapacitors that are depicted from the figure inset. Notably, the survey was performed based on the Scopus database. It could be deduced that the reporting on Prussian blue will be gone high up in the forthcoming days. Prussian blue (PB) can be structurally classified into two types of dye; insoluble PB with chemical formula Fe4[Fe(CN)6]3 and soluble PB with the general structure KFe[Fe(CN)6]. The insoluble PB dye utilized as electrodes for the field of energy storage has the formula A x Fe[Fe(CN)6]y□1– y ·mH2O where, A is alkali metal, □: vacancy of Fe(CN)6, 0 < x < 2 and 0 < y < 1) [45]. The crystal lattice of the insoluble dye is shown in Fig. 5(a) where it displays a face-centered cubic crystal containing different oxidation states of iron atoms (2+ and 3+) which are settled in the crystal sites and linked by pairs of cyano groups. Fe3+ is interconnected with the octahedral nitrogen but carbon atoms are surrounding Fe2+ ions [46]. Moreover, the lattice has 25% voids of [Fe2+(CN)6]4− clusters that are coming from the charge neutrality because of the particular ratio between Fe2+ and Fe3+ (3:4). As a result, water molecules are filled these octahedral vacancies. The water molecules are found to be positioned in two different places from the lattice; the corner where Fe3+ attached to six H2O which are called “coordinated water”, and the other place is the available eight sites 8c (1/4, 1/4, 1/4) of the unit cell which is hosting the other water molecules [47]. It is also interesting to know that when changing the mass of an alkali metal component, Prussian white and green dyes could be obtained [48,49]. On the other hand, PB structure can be modified substitutional or interstitially with maintaining the structure of the lattice to give the Prussian blue analogues (PBA). The substitutional modification involves the replacement of iron atoms with other transition metals such as manganese, zinc, copper [23,50]. Meanwhile, the interstitial functionalization is done by intercalation with alkali-metal ions. An example of the substitional modified PB is Na x MnFe(CN)6 presented by Wang and is counted as one of the most interesting PBA in the energy storage application (see Fig. 5b) [49]. From the structural view of that compound, it can be found that the Mn atom substitutes the Fe−N of the general PB structure. Mn and Fe with different oxidation states can be probably combined results in preventing the voids in the final crystal. Additionally, 8c positions reveal intercalation of sodium atoms however, their places are not fully occupied [47]. 4 PB and PBA synthesis procedures 4.1 Template free methods This procedure involves the preparation of highly stabilized charged PB and PBA nanoparticles without the assistance of capping agents by adjusting physico-chemical factors. Thus, It has the merits of being a green approach proceeded at low temperature with high yield and can be achievable used for building multilayers and nanopatterning at any modified substrates due to the purity of the nanoparticle surface. Further, this method presents a real study for the effect of coating on the desired features of the nanoparticles without changing their crystallinity, diameter, and composition which are strongly related to the relaxometric and magnetic properties [51]. For example, Yue et al. have been developed a template free and bottom-up procedure for obtaining mesoporous KNiFe(CN)6 nanoparticles (NiHCF) for being used as electrodes in sodium batteries [52]. The porosity and morphology of as-prepared PBA were manipulated by using a solvent for various time intervals to etch the pores of the structure wall. The synthesis method based on the aggregation/formation mechanism is depicted in Scheme 1 , where the interaction has happened between the metal cations and Fe(CN)6 4− ions at first leading the crystals to grow, aggregate and combine together. Then, the aggregated particles were further grown to give single granular particles. Eventually, the accumulated pores of the as-formed structure were changed into macropores using the solvent etching for long periods [53] (Scheme 2 ). In another research, Ya et al. performed a study to increase the content of sodium ions in sodium iron hexacyanoferrate for improving their performance as cathode for Na-ion batteries by applying a better reducing agent in the atmosphere of nitrogen. The reducing agent and nitrogen gas are responsible for preventing of Fe2+/[FeII(CN)6]4– from the oxidation to Fe3+/[FeIII (CN)6]3– leading to minimizing the Fe valence and hence increasing the Na content to a maximum value of 1.63 per the total formula [54]. Devaney et al. postulated also a facile template-free method for obtaining zinc hexacyanoferrate nanoparticles by incorporating various solvent mixtures from water and formamide during the zinc ions complexation with [FeIII(CN)6]3− revealing that the solvent can affect the size diameter and the properties of the final nanoparticles [55,56]. 4.2 Template-based methods 4.2.1 Microemulsion Microemulsion is the most pioneer technique for manipulating the nucleation and formation of nanomaterials [57]. Whereas the reversed micelle is water droplets dispersed in organic solvents with the help of surfactant stabilization. The surfactant molecule is usually having two different parts in their structure; the polar hydrophilic head and their hydrophobic tail that is susceptible to the interaction with the organic phase [58–60]. The water-in-oil microemulsion was introduced for the preparation of colloidal Cu2[Fe(CN)6] solutions with the assistance of sodium bis(2-ethylhexyl) sulfosuccinate (AOT) surfactant from a facile reaction of CuSO4 with K4[Fe(CN)6]. The as-produced aggregates of copper hexacyanoferrate in the microemulsion solution were found to be isotropic and follow the beer's law. As the molar ratios between water and the used surfactant were increased, there were obvious blue shifts in the UV spectra caused by the particle band transition interaction [61]. In this scenario, Fan et al. reported for the first time the preparation of superparticles from the self-assembly of PB nanocubes fabricated by using hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB)/isopropanol/cyclohexane solution with a prosperous narrow size distribution. It could be clearly observed that during the microemulsion process, the CTAB surfactant can wrap PB surface allowing the parameter of geometrical complementary to undergo the self assembly process [62]. Meanwhile, lin et al. [64] developed a new method at room temperature for the synthesis of nanocubes and octahedrons of Cd3[Co-(CN)6]2·nH2O as displayed in Scheme 2 by using sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonate (SDBS) and poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) and investigated their efficiency toward the absorption of hydrogen and carbon dioxide gases. When PVP is used as the surfactant in the reaction, it was observed smooth nanocubic crystals with a diameter of 0.8‒1 µM. Despite that, the use of only 5 mL ethanol as a solvent with water leads to the truncation of the crystals structure and the particles become smaller in size because the viscosity and polarity of solvent play a critical role in controlling the shape and size. As ethanol is more viscous than water resulting in cadmium ions moving slowly and consequently retards the nucleation and growth reactions of nanocubic structure. In the case of replacing SDBS surfactant with PVP, a rough octahedron PBA structure was obtained. Further, It was found that the surface-specific area of nanocubic structure is much higher than that of octahedron one resulted from the remaining SDBS molecules found in the framework structure which is in a good agreement with the other reported PBA crystals [63]. As a result, Cd3[Co(CN)6]2·nH2O nanocubes recorded an uptake H2 percentage of 1.3% at the conditions of pressure 1.01 × 105 Pa and temperature 77 K with an excellent absorption efficiency compared to that of the octahedron one (1.24%) [64]. 4.2.2 Polymer and ligand assisted methods The transition metals that are self-assembled using the specified polymers and coordinated ligands can manifest outstanding properties such as gas adsorption, conductivity, sustain redox ability, and so on. Inspired by the growth of nanocrystal using polymer under the property of spatial confinement will protrude an important factor for building novel nanomaterials in the future. The first report on the synthesis of well uniform PB nanoparticles adjusted by PVP was presented by Takashi [65]. The size diameter of these nanoparticles was 27 nm as confirmed by TEM (Fig. 6 a). As can be observed from Fig. 6, the concentration of Fe ions and the mass ratio between PVP and Fe2+ could manipulate the particle size diameter of PB. When the mass ratio of PVP to Fe2+ becomes 50 and 100 at 10 mM Fe ions concentration, the particle diameters were observed 20 and 16 nm, respectively (Fig. 3b and c). Furthermore, when the concentration of [Fe2+] is reduced to 1 mM and the mass ratio of PVP/Fe2+ was set at 20 and 100, it produced PB with the particle size of 25 and 12 nm, consecutively (Fig. 6d). Whereas, the more increasing of the concentration of Fe ions to 30 mM didn't succeed to obtain narrowly distributed particles and the crystal size appears to be more than 100 nm at any ratio of PVP/Fe2+. The mechanism for the preparation of PB nanoparticles by PVP was hypothesized and schematically shown in Scheme 3 . PVP has an amide linker that can coordinate with the iron ions existed on the surface of PB nanoparticles during the nucleation and growth reactions giving rise to the steric stabilization and the formation of PVP-protected PB nanoparticles [65]. Far from PVP, Ding et al. utilized the acidic hydrolysis of chitosan as a reducing agent to control the size of PB nanoparticles and nanocubes by the fast seed and the prolonged growth reactions. For undergoing the reaction for 6 days, it can be obtained discrete dots and cubes with the size ~10 nm as an indication for starting the formation of PB nanocubes. The further increase of the time to 10, 15, and 20 days, results in the complete formation of nanocubes from the nucleation of nanoparticles with the diameters of approximately 56, 80, and 90 nm, respectively. As, chitosan structure connected by 1‒4 linkage repeated along the polymer chain, the acidic solutions causes the liberation of aldehyde group acting as a reducing species for the ionized ferricyanide or ferric. Thus, the small PB particles were made by the quick hydrolysis rate of chitosan with the temperature elevation, besides the bigger particle is getting produced at the high polymer viscosity in which the hydrolysis rate is retarded [66]. Another interesting work was reported by Chen et al. for the synthesis of Na2Ni x Mn y Fe(CN)6 PBA by using sodium citrate which retards the coordination rate of nickel and manganese ions with the ferrous cyanide ions coming from the competition between citrate ions and ferrous cyanide ions to combine with the metal cations [67]. Also, an appropriate procedure for controlling the dispersion of insoluble PB in water and different hydrophobic/hydrophilic organic solvents was achieved by the surface functionalization of Fe4[Fe(CN)6]3·15H2O using Na4[FeII(CN)6] and short alkylamines chains as shown in Fig. 7 [68]. Polyethyleneimine also was found to produce stable PB particles in water with a diameter of 50 nm using a facile co-precipitation method by undergoing the reactants refluxing for 30 min [69]. It was previously reported that the tinny size of Gd(H2O)4[Fe(CN)6] that reaches 5 nm can be given using polyethylene glycol or d-mannitol for being applied in the biological field [51,70]. Another procedure to fabricate PBA (NiFe, NiCr, PB, MnCr) with diameter 1.7–5.2 nm was developed by using a mixture between oleic acid and trioctylamine to obtain the long-time stable colloidal solution in THF [71]. 5 Mathematical factors for evaluating supercapacitor electrodes The efficiency of materials that are applied as supercapacitors could be evaluated according to some specific electrochemical factors. Whereas, three type electrode system is generally utilized to measure these factors before fabricating the device. The measurement process needs three different electrodes; the reference, counter and the working electrodes dipped in an appropriated electrolyte. The device assembly can be subsequently done as a symmetrical or asymmetrical supercapacitor using two electrodes. The boundary between the electrode surfaces should be separated with the electrolyte. 5.1 Three-electrode system In three type configuration, specific capacitance (Cs measured in F/g) can be estimated from cyclic voltammograms using Eq. (2). (2) C s = 1 m s ( Δ V ) ∫ V a V c I ( V ) d V , where the integration of CV area is ∫ I d V , the active mass of electrode in g is m, the deviated potential window is ΔV and the sweep rate in mV/s is s. In addition to that, C s can be calculated from galvanic charge/discharge curves (GCD)as fellow: (3) C s = I × Δ t Δ V × m , where the applied constant current is I and discharge time (s) is Δt. Furthermore, the values of energy in Wh/kg (E s) and power in W/kg (P s) densities of the electrode could be obtained from charge-discharge curves as depicted in Eqs. (4 and 5) [21]. (4) E s = 0.5 × C s × Δ V 2 , (5) P s = E s Δ t , 5.2 Two-electrode configuration When establishing the symmetrical supercapacitor using two identical electrodes, Cs can be enumerated from GCD figures by applying the following equation: (6) C s = 4 × I × Δ t Δ V × m , where m is the total mass of both electrodes in g where m + = m − in case of symmetrical supercapacitors. Whereas, for the symmetrical device, ES and PS amounts could be found in Eqs. (7 and 8) [72]. (7) E s = 1 × C s × ( Δ V 2 ) 4 × 2 × 3.6 , (8) P s = E s × 3600 Δ t . 6 Nanostructured PB and PBAs for supercapacitor application Nowadays, PB and their derivatives have been received a lot of concerns to be used in the field of energy as electrodes for supercapacitors and batteries. The electrochemical features can be generally enhanced through various procedures; (i) tailoring the electrode conductivity using chemical or physical routes, (ii) controlling the synthesis method to obtain high surface area and (iii) making binder-free electrodes [73]. Also, it was aforementioned that the supercapacitor electrode ability to store energy depends on the nature of its material. As a result, PB and alternatives could be the correct way of being electrodes because of several reasons. The first cause is that the structure of PB could facilitate the physisorption of electrolyte ions inside the electrode surface. Another one is the redox ability of PB which is an important factor for storing energy. Further, nanoporous carbon decorated with metal nanoparticles could be obtained by thermal heating of PB and PBA in an inert atmosphere as a way to get a high surface area. PB and PBA can be also modified to metal oxides by the pyrolysis in air. These reasons for PB and PBA could make them high-performance supercapacitors through the excellent surface area and the high charge conduction of their structures [21]. 6.1 Pure PB and PBA Coordination supramolecular networks (CSNs), are counted to be a novel class of supramolecules that are formed from the inclusion of metal ions or clusters into an organic ligand via a weak binding such as coordination and hydrogen bonds. Very recently, they have been explored as electrodes due to the weak interaction between the metal and ligand is sufficient to build frameworks with excellent dynamic reversibility, pore structure adjustability, and self-healing ability. These features are very critical for improving the transfer of charges, easy movement of electrolyte ions and enhancing the final capacitance of the electrode [74,75]. On the other hand, metal hexacyanoferrates are also considered as a member of the family of PB or PBA nanostructures and their open channel always attracts the concerns for being used as advanced supercapacitor materials. As their structure endorses the movement of electrolyte inside the electrode to be active sites redox reaction. Zhao et al. [76] were firstly reported the use of low-cost cobalt hexacyanoferrate nanoparticles (CHCF); the derivatives of Prussian blue as high stable and performance electrode for supercapacitors. The particles were simply prepared by a coprecipitation method from the precursors of Co(NO3)2 and K3Fe(CN)6 with the molar ratio 3:2 under the vigorous stirring for 1 h to form an interconnected porous structure with the size diameter ~20 nm. However, they have poor crystallinity and thermal stability. By applying this material as supercapacitors, the three-electrode method in the aqueous electrolyte 0.5 M Na2SO4 shows a specific capacitance of more than 250 F/g from CV at a lower scan rate of 5 mV/s with (−0.1‒1.1 V) potential window. It was also observed a pair of faradic peaks located at ~ 0.4 V coming from the redox reaction of FeII/III in Cobalt hexacyanoferrate resulting in the charge neutrality by sodium ions of the inner and outer surface of the metal framework. In the charge-discharge test, the electrode reveals a remarkable plateaus at 0.4–0.5 V related to the position of redox peaks as previously described from the CV pattern. Besides, the material appears with curves of high symmetry corresponding to their excellent reversibility and fast reactions. Their specific capacitance was calculated as ~250 F/g at 1 A/g and reduced to ~60 F/g at 50 A/g corresponding to an excellent retention rate. The cobalt hexacyanoferrate also displayed an excellent cycle stable life up to 5000 cycles with a capacitance loss of only 6.5%. Moreover, this material was mingled with modified graphene as a negative electrode in an asymmetrical device that could enlarge the potential window up to ~ 2.4 V. In the same trend, another work for the facile synthesis of cobalt hexacyanoferrate nanocubes (CoHCF) with mesopores and high surface area of 548.5 m2/g using a sacrificial template of manganese hexacyanoferrate prepared using PVP has been presented. The size of the nanocubes was in the range from 300 to 500 nm and with well uniform dispersed mesopores of bout 4.6 nm. CoHCF was then applied as a supercapacitor electrode which exhibited in (0.5 M) Na2SO4 electrolyte, a specific capacitance of 285 F/g, stable cycle life after 3000 cycles achieving capacity retention of 92.9% and an improved rate capability [77]. Zhang et al. [78] developed an interesting flexible supercapacitor from the grown of coordination supramolecular network of Prussian blue (denoted as CSN-PB) electrochemically on the carbon cloth followed by the electrochemical deposition of manganese oxide to form a novel binder-free CSN-PB/MnO2 composite electrode on the cloth as shown in Fig. 8 . They inspired by the synergistic factor in the capacitance arising from the combination of the porous open structure of PB with MnO2 where the composite could achieve a high operating value of 1.4 V in the aqueous electrolyte with a specific capacitance of 315.3 F/g. It was interesting also when making an asymmetrical device from CSN-PB/MnO2 composite as cathode and the anode was activated carbon, It can works in potential range up to 2.4 V with an excellent energy density (46.13 Wh/kg) and capacitance retention reaches to 85.5% after 20,000 cycles at an applied current density of 20 A/g. A further study was given for the synthesis of the insoluble nickel (NiHCF), cobalt (CoHCF) and iron (FeHCF) hexacyanoferrates as supercapacitors using the commonly reported precipitation method, where their morphology is displayed in Fig. 9 . It could be noticed that all particles show a spherical shape where the diameter of FeHCF, NiHCF, and CoHCF is about 60, 20 and 15 nm, respectively. When fabricating the working electrode by mixing 75 wt.% of the three particles individually with 5 wt.% PTFE binder and 20 wt.% acetylene black and then was pressed on the stainless steel, the specific capacitance from CD was recorded as 425, 574.7 and 261.56 F/g for FeHCF, NiHCF and CoHCF, consecutively and the particles were of an excellent cyclic ability [79]. Safavi et al. [80] postulated a cyclic voltammetric method for the electrodeposition of mixed structure from nickel and cobalt hexacyanoferrate on stainless steel substrate without using any binder to inhibit the resistance of the electrode. The reaction was done by dipping the electrode in a mixture of 1 M KNO3 and the precursors followed by applying 25 cycles in the potential range 0‒0.85 with 50 mV/s sweeping rate. From Fig. 10 (a‒c), the morphology of the as-prepared electrode was controlled based on the molar ratio of Ni to Co in the reaction. In case of the molar ratio was set at 1, a high surface area nanostructure composed from particles of size diameter 40 nm was obtained. Whereas It could be seen a partial aggregated structure in the other molar ratios of Ni and Co, in addition to the dispersion becomes worse in the case of the as-prepared pure Ni and Co nanostructured electrodes. As a result, the specific capacitance for the hybrid metal cyanoferrate nanostructure (molar ratio = 1) was 765 F g−1 compared to other molar ratios, and the virgin nickel hexacyanoferrate (379 F g−1) and cobalt hexacyanoferrate (277 F g−1) (Fig. 10d). Besides, the excellent capacitance, longer cyclability, and good stability behavior were confirmed from Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and CD tests. Another method for the preparation of microporous and mesoporous cobalt hexacyanoferrate nanocubes was proposed by Zhaoxia et al. [81] through the application of sodium tricitrate as a complexing agent during the precipitation method. The produced nanocubes were then used as a positive electrode along with the negative activated carbon to make asymmetric supercapacitors with long cycle life. The morphology was successfully manipulated by the existence of the complexing agent and changing the molar ratios of K3[Fe(CN)6]/CoCl2 to 1/3, 2/3 and 3/3 to give samples codes CoHCF-1, −2 and −3, respectively and the sample without sodium tricitrate referred to CoHCF-1 as shown in Table 1 and Fig. 11 . As was clearly described from SEM images that the preparation of CoHCF nanocubes was prosperously achieved with the help of sodium tricitrate and its absence causes the aggregation of the particles and the nanocubes growth failure. The complexing agent plays a critical role in the crystallization process of CoHCF. The structure of citrate derivative has three COOH groups that can interact covalently with Co cations to produce complexes and hence, slow down the nucleation rate of the particles that result in synthesizing well uniform nanocube particles. Sodium tricitrate could also be exposed to the adsorption on the surface of the nanocubes and acts as inhibitors for particle aggregation (see Fig. 11a–d). This effect can be obviously noticed from BET and specific capacitance shown in Table 1. CV pattern of the samples CoHCF-0 and −1 found in Fig. 11(e) gives a good indication that the formation of CoHCF nanocubes enhances the charge transfer properties and the capacitance of the electrode. Nevertheless, the CV curve area and capacitance values of CoHCF nanoparticles decrease with increasing the molar ratio of K3[Fe(CN)6]/CoCl2 (Fig. 11f and g). When CoHCF nanocubes were used to fabricate an asymmetric device with the activated carbon (AC) as an anode, two different working voltages of −0.9‒0.1 and 0.1‒0.8 V were obtained for activated carbon and the sample coded CoHCF-1, respectively (Fig. 11h). Moreover, the device can have the ability to give an energy density output of 17.4 Wh/kg at a power density of 136 W/kg. However, when the power density reaches a high value (1196 W/kg), the energy density was 9.1 Wh/kg. The cycle stability curve of the as-made device was done at a current density 1 A/g up to 6000 cycles retaining 91% from their starting capacitance corresponding to the considerable cycle life (Fig. 11i and j). Another research group tried to develop an inspired method for the preparation of uniform nanocubes manganese hexacyanoferrate (MnHCF) at room temperature using PVP as a surface directing agent [82]. The as-synthesized MnHCF was found to have dual functions as a supercapacitor electrode and a sensor for H2O2 in buffer solutions. The materials appeared a single crystalline nanocube with a diameter of 650 nm (Fig. 12 a), a surface area of 512 m2/g and a pore diameter of 4.5 nm. By utilizing the fascinated porosity feature of MnHCF nanocubes to facilitate the movement of electrolyte ions into the electrode surface and allow the electrochemical reaction to proceed, MnHCF electrode in 1.0 M K2SO4 solution can show CV patterns found in Fig. 12(b) that are completely different from the electrical double layer one and are related to the pseudocapacitive manner. The specific capacitance at a low scan rate (5 mV/s) was noted at 715 F/g which is remarkably increased concerning to the previously reported value for cobalt hexacyanoferrate [76]. The specific capacitance calculated from CD curves was also found to be 690 F/g at 1.3 A/g and when applying the highest current density value of 10 A/g, its value was diminished to 297 F/g (Fig 12c and d). The authors mentioned a proposal for the redox reactions of MnHCF nanocubes: (9) M n II [ Fe III ( CN ) 6 ] + n A + + e − = A n M n II [ F e II ( CN ) 6 ] , where A is the intercalated alkaline cation and A+ is its corresponded alkaline cation in the solution. Also, MnHCF is a member of the Prussian blue family that has in its structure iron atoms and can undergo a redox reaction between the oxidized ferric and reduced ferrous under a certain potential. It was aforesaid that the charge can be also neutralized by the reversible intercalation and deintercalation of alkali cations during the reaction and can be a further mechanism to understand the excellent electrochemical properties of MnHCF [82]. In another work, 3D hierarchical thin films formed from the hybridization of MnHCF with CoHCF using the facile electrochemical deposition on a substrate from a glassy carbon electrode. Besides, they were tested as electrodes for the supercapacitor and water oxidation. The obtained thin films were found to have a specific capacitance of 350 F/g at 1 A/cm2 applied current density [83]. Very recently, Xuemin et al. [84] discovered an easy method for preparing CoHCF with controlled hollow structures using previously reported water-soluble templates; cobalt acetate hydroxide prism, zeolitic imidazolate framework polyhedron (ZIF-67) and co-glycerate sphere. The length and width of the as-produced CoHCF hollow prisms were measured as 2.5 µm and 500 nm, respectively, besides, the thickness was 100 nm (Fig. 13 a‒c). The particle size for the sphere and polyhedron particles was not reported. CV pattern of CoHCF nano prisms is depicted in Fig. 13(d), where a pair of redox peaks was appeared at 0.4 V due to the oxidation/reduction of Fe2+/3+ presented in the structure of CoHCf and was confirmed from the slopped plateaus (0.3–0.5) in the CD curves that are found in Fig. 13(e) from 1 to 20 A/g. The specific capacitance in the electrolyte of 0.5 M Na2SO4 was recorded for nano prisms, spheres, and polyhydrons as 284, 255.6 and 285.6 F/g respectively, while the rate performance from 1 to 20 A/g was found to be 64%, 45% and 48%, respectively. The cycle life stability of hollow prisms after 5000 cycles (92%) was much higher compared to the hollow spheres (81%) and polyhedrons (85%). To further investigate the applicable performance of nano prisms particles, the asymmetrical device has been assembled with activated carbon extending the operating voltage to 2.0 V and can deliver a capacitance of 81 F/g at 1 A/g. The cell also can withstand the cycling up to 3000 cycles with capacitance loss of only 7.55%. Xueying et al. [85] utilized a simple hydrothermal method at 120 °C to decorate ZnCo-PBA spheres (between 50 and 100 nm) with α-Cobalt hydroxide nanosheets with a good electrochemical performance. The electrode was tested in an electrolyte of 1 M KOH where it exhibited 423.92 F/g specific capacitance at the discharge current 1 A/g with a little good cycling life reserving capacitance of 78.48% after 1000 cycles at 5 A/g. While the assembly of the as-prepared positive electrode with the negative activated carbon electrode in a hybrid device using 6 M KOH as electrolyte appeared a capacitance of 122.4 F/g with a tested cycle life up to 5000 cycles at 5 A/g and obtaining a remaining retention of 73.53% and an excellent energy density of 49.13 Wh/kg with 1734 W/kg power density. 6.2 PB/PBA@carbon hybrid materials Pristine PB and PBA were found to follow the pseudocapacitive behavior for charge transfer mechanisms showing a good capacitive property, despite, they are suffering from the disadvantages of bad cycle life, retention rate and not achieving the desired values of energy/power densities. This is because the electrochemical properties are partially decayed against increasing the cycles due to the fast redox processes that happened at the interface between the electrode and electrolyte. Consequently, there should be a great effort to discover new materials that are working by non-redox mechanisms and can be mixed with PB or PBA. These materials are known as electrical double-layer materials and can store the charge electrostatically at the boundary between the electrode and the electrolyte as discussed above [86]. PB/PBA can be hybridized with various nanomaterials such as carbon, metal oxide, conducting polymers. The combination with carbon materials such as carbon hydrogel, carbon nanotubes, activated carbon, graphene is of great importance as it can show a synergism phenomena combining the excellent mechanical, thermal, electronic properties, low toxicity, and lightweight. Thus, the integration of PB or PBA with carbon derivatives can be a good way of solving their weaknesses and enhancing other properties such as electrical conductivity, cycles life, and the specific capacitance which will be discussed below. Yafei et al. [87] established new in-plane micro-supercapacitors (AMSCs) with the considerable long cycle life, better rate capability, high capacitance by sandwiching stainless steel substrate with graphene and metal hexacyanoferrate (CuHCF, NiHCF, CoHCF, and FeHCF) as the negative electrode beside the graphene that was used as the positive electrode as found in Fig. 14 . The electrolyte was made by mixing LiCl and PVA polymer. The output of the potential window of the established device was increased up to 1.8 V and can be delivered an areal capacitance of 19.84 F/cm2 and a superior energy density value of 44.6 mWh/cm3 with 96.8% retention ratio achieved after running 5000 cycles. In a different work, the polymer of diallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDDA) was interestingly used to control the formation of NiHCF nanocubes (NBs) on the surface of reduced graphene oxide. The polymer has been initially functionalized the surface of graphene oxide (GO) and then followed by the in situ co-precipitation of NBs precursors produced well-dispersed nanocubes on PDDA/rGO surface due to the electrostatic interaction. The size of NBs crystals could be changed from 10 to 85 nm based on their content percentage presented in the total weight of the ternary nanocomposite. When the NiHCF/PDDA/rGO composite contains NiHCF NBs with 51.4%, the mean diameter of the particles was found to be 38 nm. By evaluating the electrochemical properties of the as-prepared hybrids, the specific capacitance was observed to be 1320 F/g at a current density 0.2 A/g which was more than two times as compared to that of the pure NiHCF revealing the vital role of graphene incorporation in the composite and the well dispersion of the particles on the capacitance properties of the final electrode. The initial capacitance was also found to be decreased by 15% after doing 10,000 cycles at 0.2 A/g besides the delivery of 58.7 Wh/kg energy density at a power density of 80 W/kg [88]. Also, Xiaoming et al. prepared an electrode with an enhanced electrochemical property as supercapacitors from a nanocomposite of nickel–cobalt hexacyanoferrate/reduced graphene oxide. The preparation method was adapted using the reverse microemulsion technique to inhibit the agglomeration of PBA on the graphene surface. The electrode can be applied for the supercapacitors and sodium-ion batteries together as they can achieve a capacitance of 466 F/g at 0.2 A/g and could be only decreased to 350 F/g in case of applying a current density of 10 A/g and they can exhibit enhanced cycle stability as well. In the case of being used as a cathode for sodium-ion batteries, they can give an excellent reversible capacity of 118 mAh/g at 0.1 A/g [89]. Shahram et al. were the first to report the synthesis of graphene/nickel–iron–hexacyanoferrate (graphene/Ni–Fe–HCF) using the electrochemical deposition technique. The graphene oxide was initially coated on stainless steel substrate (SS) through electrophoretic deposition method and was then reduced electrochemically (ERGO) in an electrolyte of sodium nitrate under a constant potential −1.1 V to give ERGO/SS. After that, the nickel–iron–hexacyanoferrate nanoparticles with the diameter range of 20‒60 nm were deposited on ERGO/SS using the chronoamperometry technique. The final electrode was investigated as energy storage material where the nanocomposite of Ni–Fe–HCF/ERGO shows a higher capacity (67.77 mAh/g) with respect to the pure Ni–Fe–HCF(20.97 mAh/g) and ERGO (32.5 mAh/g) at 0.5 A/g [90]. Different nanocomposite from graphene and CoHCF nanoparticles was fabricated with good electrochemical properties as an electrode which can achieve 361 F/g specific capacitance in the sodium sulfate as an electrolyte. The as-prepared CoHCF anchored on the surface of reduced graphene was found to have a size diameter of almost 50 nm. When the nanocomposite electrode was assembled with AC (negative electrode) in an asymmetrical device, It could be work up to 2 V with 39.6 Wh/kg energy density opening the gate to be used as promising supercapacitors [91]. It was previously reported that a remarkable decrease in the specific capacitance of CoHCF and NiHCF was observed when being coated on the stainless steel current collector after performing 1000 CD cycles [79,92]. For a different work showed the same behavior of capacitance decrease in case of NiHCF deposition on nickel foams because the nickel substrate was partially corroded producing excess nickel ions that were found to be insoluble and located in the sites of potassium counter cations affecting the output voltage of the system [93]. In general, the serious fading noticed in the capacitance was related to the substrate partial corrosion leading to maximizing the internal resistance of the electrode. Consequently, it is very important to form a compact layer from carbon materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the substrates that will be coated with MHCF to enhance their capacitance efficiency. Mao-sung et al. [94] utilized this approach for improving the capacitance of stainless steel coated with copper and nickel hexacyanoferrate (CuHCF and NiHCF) by adding a conductive and corrosion protective carbon film from carbon black and graphene or CNTs between SS and CuHCF. The electrophoretic deposition method was used directly to form the carbon layer on the SS substrate and for co-precipitating MHCF nanoparticles on the carbon-coated SS. The authors found that a layer from graphene (GN) layer on SS current collector was efficient for its corrosion inhibition compared to the porous CNTs. In addition, the decoration of CuHCF on the graphene-coated SS electrode gave a specific capacitance of 570 F/g that was higher than when deposited on the platinum electrode (Pt) without using the carbon layer (500 F/g) at 1 A/g and with a greater capacitance retention (96%) after 1000 cycles in relation to that of CuHCF coated Pt (75%). Reduced graphene hydrogel (rGOH) was also mixed with cobalt hexacyanoferrate (PB-Co) using on step hydrothermal method as shown in Fig. 15(a) to give a strong 3D interconnected structure PB-(Co/rGOH) with a high specific capacitance performance of 220 F/g and long cycle life where it achieved a retention ratio of 83% after 10,000 cycles under applying a constant 5 A/g [95]. Noteworthy, the electrochemical properties of PB–Co/rGOH samples such as CV and CD were measured using a 3-type electrode in an aqueous electrolyte from 1 mol/L KNO3 as depicted in Fig. 15(b and c). The samples of PB-Co (0.3)/rGOH, PB-Co and rGOH were together compared through CV at a scan rate at 10 mV/s, where the rGOH exhibited a rectangular curve from a voltage range of −1‒1 V corresponding to EDLC mechanism. Meanwhile, the PB-Co samples were conversely displayed a two redox peaks at 0.5–0.7 V. It was fascinating when incorporating PB-Co nanoparticles in graphene hydrogel (PB-Co/rGOH), the deconvolution of its CV curve contains both the rectangular shape of EDLC and the area of pseudo-capacitance found at 0.2–0.8 V (Fig. 15b). The same results were also confirmed from CD curves shown in Fig. 15(c). Besides, when a flexible symmetrical device from the as-prepared PB-Co/rGOH, it gives 2 V working voltage with a comparable and interesting energy density (57.5 Wh/kg) to that of Ni/MH batteries (60–120 Wh kg−1). The superb capacitance and cycling stability of PB-Co/rGOH electrode seen in Fig. 15(d and e) might come from many reasons; (1) the PB-Co particles crosslinked with the graphene hydrogel preventing their aggregation and graphene sheet gathering together for improving the capacitance parameter, (2) the graphene oxide was completely reduced through the hydrothermal method leading to the potential window range extension, (3) the direct contact of graphene sheets with the PB-Co particles as faradic centers without resistance for obtaining high capacitance, and (4) 3D- interconnected structure of PB-Co/rGOH gives a good chance for electrolyte ions to be freely moved inside the electrode and the facile occurrence of electrochemical reaction results in the high retention rate and capacitance ability. Targholi et al. [96] synthesized another nanocomposite from CuHCF and reduced graphene with the help of thiourea as a reducing agent. The electrochemical efficiency of the as-prepared nanocomposite was fully enhanced compared to the pure rGO and CuHCF where the specific capacitance of electrode in 0.5 M potassium sulfate was detected as 548 F/g at a current density 0.5 A/g with the operating voltage of −0.2‒1 V showing a synergism factor between rGO and CuHCF. The capacitance retention of the as-produced electrode was found to be 83% from the starting capacitance after one thousand cycles at 3 A/g. Another nanocomposite produced from mixing of MnHCF with only 20 wt% of graphene oxide has a specific capacitance of 279 F/g which is almost more higher three times compared to the pure MnHCF electrode and can achieve 65.3% retention from the initial capacitance after 2000 cycles at 0.8 A/g [97]. The same nanocomposite was prepared in 3D porous nanostructure by the anodic galvanostatic pulse electrodeposition (GPED). The graphite substrate was coated with nanoplatelets from graphene oxide by the technique of EPD which followed by the reduction using an electrochemical method. MnHCF nanocubes were then decorated regularly on the surface of rGO nanosheets by the GPED method to obtain a porous MnHCF/rGO hybrid electrode. The as-fabricated electrode without binder was found to deliver a specific capacitance of 612 F/g at 1.0 A/g beside a stable cycle life up to 2000 cycles with a retention ratio of 93.8%. Meanwhile, their assemble in an asymmetric device with the negative rGO electrode obtain an energy density of 45.3 Wh/kg with a voltage up to 1.9 V and long cycling life with good capacitance retention (91.2%, 4000 cycles) [98]. Other carbon materials representing EDLCs are carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and were used to improve the electrochemical stability and the electrical conductivity of the metal hexacyanoferrates. On the contrary, the virgin CNTs have a low value of specific capacitance that cannot satisfy the standard specifications for the commercial supercapacitors. The research on the combination of CNTs with PB or PBA is scarcely reported. Yunyun et al. [99] gave a new approach for the preparation of a coaxial core/shell structure from nickel hexacyanoferrate/multiwalled carbon nanotubes nanocables (NiHCF/MWCNTs). MWCNTs were primarily grafted with poly(4-vinylpyridine) and then was uniformly decorated with NiHCF. It was notable that the loading of NiHCF on MWCNTs with different mass ratios was conducted. It was clearly observed that the specific capacitance of the prepared electrode from NiHCF/MWCNTs was 1035 F/g at the constant current of 0.05 A/g with noticed a small loss (10%) in the capacitance at 25.6 A/g and 56.2 Wh/kg energy density. The retention was also found after 10,000 cycles 92.7% at the current density 2 A/g. CNTs also were used as conductive skeletons to carry the nickel–cobalt hexacyanoferrate (K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6) for the fast transport of electrons and ions between the particles and enhancing the final capacitance [100]. The schematic representation for the preparation of the hybrid composite of K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6/CNTs is observed in Fig. 16 (a). The particle size diameter of K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6 was found to be almost 20 nm (Fig. 16b). As depicted also from Fig. 16(c), the remarkable change in the CV area between the K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6/CNTs and the pure K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6 electrodes where the hybrid electrode shows a bigger area compared to the pristine K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6 and CNTs indicating the efficient capacitance ability that comes from the successful combining of PBA with CNTs. This is also confirmed that the uniform dispersed K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6 nanoparticles into the surface of CNTs skeletons shortens the way that is taken by the ions and hence enhances the performance of active materials and the ability to store the energy. It can be notified also that the value for the difference in potential between the reduction and oxidation peaks of K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6/CNTs hybrid at 20 mV/s scan rate is recorded as 0.23 V that is lower than gotten from K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6 (0.39 V) as an indication for fasting the kinetics of the reversible redox reaction when adding CNTs. It was surprising that the obtained potential difference value is too much lower compared with the other reported materials that are working by pseudocapacitance mechanisms such as Ni–Co LDH based electrode (≈0.3 V at a scan rate of 10 mV/s) [101]. Notably, PBA electrodes were differentially found to work in the potential range 0‒1 V that is broader compared to that of a metal oxide such as nickel hydroxide (0‒0.5 V) resulted in increasing their energy density and be a promising candidate for the future energy applications. These data were fully evidenced by the obtained specific capacitance against the discharge current shown in Fig. 16(d). The K2.25Ni0.55Co0.37Fe(CN)6/CNTs could deliver a capacitance value of 600 F/g at a current density of 0.2 A/g with a superior retention rate (90.4%) when the current density is decreased to 5 A/g. The electrode with the hybrid material was observed with a stable cycling performance up to 2000 cycles with a remaining capacitance of 94% (Fig. 16e). Another research group discovered the mingling of different PBA such as MnHCF nanocubes with MWCNTs in different masses using the common co-precipitation method. It could be found that the tube structure of MWCNTs was totally intertwined and enclosed the MnHCF nanocubes to form 3D porous structure as an essential demand for facilitating the electrochemical reaction and improving the stability of electrode with time. A sever synergistic factor was noticed between MWCNTs and MnHCF when measuring the electrochemical properties of their electrode where MnHCF/MWCNTs electrode obtained capacitance of 370.4 C/g which is higher with respect to that of MWCNTs (45.8 C/g) and MnHCF (200.1 C/g). The capacitance attained after 2000 cycles at 1 A/g was 87.4% [102]. Xiaojuan et al. were the first to introduce the nanocomposite of MWCNTs with CoHCF that was prepared by a straightforward chemical precipitation method achieving unreasonable specific capacitance (648.5 F/g) at 1.4 A/g as an electrode with remarkable stability (94.3%) when doing cycling up to 3000 cycles with 25% mass ratio from MWCNTs based on the total weight of the nanocomposite [103]. Other authors tried to develop a ternary flexible nanocomposite from single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), CuHCF and the polymer poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-poly(styrenesulfonate) through the vacuum filtration method. The nanocomposite was found with superior conductivity, rate capability, longer cycle stability besides the areal and volumetric capacitances at 5 mV/s sweeping rate were achieved the values of 969.8 mF/cm2 and 775.2 F/cm3, respectively. The energy density of 30.08 Wh/L at a power density of 4.25 kW/L was acquired when they were gathered with the negative Mo-doped WO3/SWCNTs electrode in an asymmetrical cell opening the gate for enhancing the volumetric ability of supercapacitors and achieving the desired energy density for the specified applications [104]. 6.3 PB/PBA@conducting polymer As was above discussed that PB and their alternatives appeared with a porous structure and high surface area. Nevertheless, they are suffering from lower conductivity and specific capacitance in addition to their energy and power densities were down the standard level for the commercial necessity. Many approaches have been used to overcome these faults such as the process of combining these materials with conducting polymers such as polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (Ppy), and polythiophene due to their feasible preparation method, excellent pseudocapacitance ability, and simple device fabrication for market applicability. The addition of conducting polymer to PB has been usually proven to produce an electrode for supercapacitors with improved electrochemical features compared to their constituents. Polyaniline is vastly used for this purpose because of its good redox capability and easy preparation method [21]. For instance, the flexible carbon fiber substrate (FCF) was decorated with a composite of polyaniline/manganese hexacyanoferrate (PANI/MnHCF) by one-step electrochemical co-precipitation and polymerization method using the cyclic voltammetry for 30 cycles in a potential range −0.2–1.0 V at 50 mV/s (Fig. 17 a) to give self-supporting electrode with superb mechanical and electrochemical properties. The MnHCF morphology as shown in Fig. 17(b) was found to be spherical nanoparticles with a diameter range of 150‒200 nm [105]. The electrochemical performance of the as-fabricated electrode was evaluated by CV and CD tests. The CV of the electrode in Fig. 17(c) was taken at 2 mV/s and could be described by the existence of three oxidation/reduction peaks evidenced from the charge and discharge curves at different current densities and corresponded to the incidence of three redox processes (Fig 17d). The first faradic peaks have happened at potentials of about +0.18 and −0.11 V related to the change of leucoemeraldine form to emeraldine. The other two redox peaks located at an approximately +0.46 and +0.39 V were ascribed to the faradic reactions occurred in the structure of PBA (Fe2+ to Fe3+) and at +0.7 and +0.58 V is designated for the diversion of emeraldine to the pernigraniline one. Kulesza et al. [106,107] previously described that there is an electrostatic interaction between the positive charge on PANI and the negative charge on metal hexacyanoferrate. The as-prepared PANI/MnHCF/FCF electrode was observed to have an excellent specific capacitance of 730 F/g at a current density of 1 A/g with an outstanding capacitance retention rate (350 F/g at 20 A/g), a cyclic capacitance reservation 85% when performing 1000 cycles. Polypyrrole (Ppy) as another interesting conducting polymer has been also composited electrochemically with NiCoHCF on a substrate from the inexpensive stainless steel. The electrochemical behavior of the electrode was studied in both the aqueous 0.5 M K2SO4 and the organic electrolyte from LiClO4/ethylene carbonate: dimethyl carbonate. The data revealed that the amalgamation of Ppy with NiCoHCF in a new nanocomposite appeared an increase in the specific capacitance at 1 A/g current density to 529 and 668 F/g, respectively for the aqueous and organic electrolytes compared to the pure Ppy. Additionally, the electrode appeared superior energy density (87 Wh/kg) at the power density 5600 W/kg) and stability 90% after 1000 cycles [108]. Ppy was further involved with GO and Prussian blue for preparing a ternary Ppy/PB/GO nanocomposite via the simultaneous polymerization of polypyrrole and formation of PB on the surface of graphene oxide using ferric chloride. The pyrrole is not only considered as a source of polypyrrole but a reducing agent for changing Fe3+ to Fe2+ and the formation of PB. Notably, the mass ratio between K3Fe(CN)6 and GO can greatly affect the size and the density of PB nanocubes on the graphene oxide surface where the mean size was found from 30 to 50 nm. The electrochemical study of the ternary nanocomposite electrode uncovered that the capacitance at 5 A/g was 525.4 F/g using 1 mol/L KNO3 electrolyte which was higher compared to the other two couples electrodes (PPy/PB and Ppy/GO nanocomposites with an eminent capacitance retaining of 96% after 2000 cycles [109]. Chaitali et al. [110] also fabricated an advanced ternary nanocomposite from cobalt hexacyanoferrate/carbon nanofibers/polypyrrole (CoHCF/CNF/Ppy) with an outstanding energy density of 102 Wh/kg at a power density of 628 W/kg and a specific capacitance of 512 F/g at 0.5 A/g. The ternary material was sophisticated via a green and costive method by the pyrrole polymerization in the existence of a mixture from the carbon nanofiber and CoHCF. The authors used CNF as a substrate for the easily dispersion and growth of CoHCF besides its contribution to the capacitance storage mechanism. Yonghong et al. incorporated sulfonated carbon nanotubes (s-CNTs) with PANI and NiHCF in a nanocomposite with a 3D porous structure on a platinum sheet as a current collector through the electropolymerization of aniline by cyclic voltammetry technique in a media from sCNTs, nickel sulfate and K3Fe(CN)6. It was spotted that the structure of ternary nanocomposite was significantly affected by the molarity variation of nickel sulfate and K3Fe(CN)6. When their concentration value was low, the morphology of the nanocomposite can be revealed as a tubular nanostructure, whereas the concentration of both nickel sulfate and K3Fe(CN)6 was adjusted to 4 mol/L, an obvious interconnected coral-like structure imputed to the π–π stacking interaction between sCNTs, NiHCF, and PANI. Over and above, the capacitance of the composite was found to be 430.77 F/g [111]. 6.4 PB/PBA-derived materials Pristine PB or PBA is essentially considered as one of the porous crystalline nanomaterials with a three-dimensional morphology that is composed of metal and organic ligands. Thus, the coordination interaction between the two constituents can be adjusted to control the distribution of pores and the surface area of the final structure. Nevertheless, the shortcoming of depressed capacitance and stability were existed and could be limited their uses as supercapacitor electrodes. Thence, PB or PBA can be exploited as preceding for the preparation of porous carbon materials, metal oxides, metal phosphides, and metal sulfides. The derivatives that could be obtained from PB and PBA can expedite the perfection of the electrode efficiency for the supercapacitor application [112]. For example, the hollow mesoporous nanocubes of cobalt sulphide (CoS2) were obtained from Co–Co Prussian blue analogue (Co–Co PBA) nanocubes through two steps. An easy precipitation method was used for producing Co–Co PBA with a diameter of 0.5 µm and were then calcined in air at 450 °C for 2 h to form Co3O4 with the same size as the used precursors. For obtaining CoS2 with the size of 400 nm, Co3O4 was at first treated hydrothermally with Na2S as a sulfur source at 160 °C for 6 h and then exposed to the heating in an inert atmosphere for 2 h at 350 °C. Due to the high surface area, the electrochemical behavior of the obtained cobalt sulfides was totally changed ensuring a high capacitance value. When being used as electrodes for supercapacitors they can be worked by the two mechanisms of EDLC (carbon derived ligand) and faradic the coming from the metal sulfide which are very important for obtaining high-performance electrode capacity and cycle stability [113]. Furthermore, many research groups are investigating the utilization of PB or PBA to obtain metal derivatives. Fangming et al. [114] synthesized different porous metal oxides nanocubes containing iron oxides such as NiO/Fe3O4, Co3O4/Fe3O4, NiO/Co3O4/Fe3O4 from the three PBA; Ni–Fe PBA, Co-Fe PBA, and Co/Ni–Fe PBA. PBA nanocubes were prepared using the surface directing agents of sodium citrate and PVP, then they were heated into a tubular furnace at 500 °C for 2 h in an air atmosphere and the heating rate was 2 °C/min. When they were applied as electrodes for supercapacitor, the NiO/Co3O4/Fe3O4 material could deliver at 1 A/g a gravimetric capacitance of 529 F/g that was more higher 2.3 and 3.7 times with respect to the two coupled metal oxide NiO/Fe3O4 and Co3O4/Fe3O4, respectively manifesting a longer cycle behavior with good stability. Also, lin et al. [115] worked on the gathering of melamine derived graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) with PB derived iron oxide (α-Fe2O3) nanoparticles. These nanoparticles could help in improving the dispersion of g-C3N4 sheets for obtaining a high surface area that is partially responsible for the enhancement of the electrode capacitance. The melamine and PB were found to be heated in the tube furnace at 550 °C for 4 h in an inert atmosphere of nitrogen. The nanocomposite was noticed to achieve a capacitance in 1.0 M KOH of 580 F/g and with good cycling up to 1000 cycles. Also, carbon nanowires (NCWs) doped with nitrogen derived from the pyrolysis of Ppy were decorated with PB that was formed on a substrate of carbon fibers (CFs) giving an anodic electrode with an outstanding areal and volumetric capacitance of 12.4 mF/cm2 and 39.6 mF/cm3. Besides, when It was mixed with the cathode manganese dioxide/titanium nitride in applicable advice, It exhibited a prolonged potential extend of 2 V and 6.1 mF/cm specific capacitance (at 10 mV/s scan rate) [116]. Shunsuke et al. [117] tried to insert PB derived iron oxide between the layers of GO to design a facile electrical road for ions of an electrolyte by the thermal degradation of different weight ratios of GO/PB in the air at 400 °C. The nanocomposite with the GO/PB mass ratio of 25/75 was observed to have a higher BET value of 120 m2/g in a comparison with the pure iron oxide and GO showing more value of specific capacitance (91 F/g at 20 mV/s scan rate). Another way was introduced for the synthesis of mesoporous Co(OH)2 nanocubes from the PBA (Co3[Co(CN)6]2) by adding 0.02 M of sodium hydroxide. The mesoporous metal hydroxide was found to have a BET value of 297 m2/g and 420 F/g specific capacitance at 1 A/g with an exquisite retention rate and good cycling performance up to 5000 cycles [118]. An inspired work was demonstrated by Rahul et al. [119] for designing nanoporous architectures derived from coordination polymers (CPs) which were then used for developing an asymmetrical device for the supercapacitor field with unexpected energy and power values, longer cycle stability as well in 6 M KOH electrolyte. The cathode nanoporous carbon (NPC) of the developed cell was prepared from simply carbonizing zinc-containing zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) at 800 °C for 5 h followed by removing the zinc species by the acid etching, whereas the anode of nanoporous nickel oxide (NPN) was formed from heating the cyano linked CPs of PBA at 300 °C in air for 60 min (See Fig. 18 a). From the SEM image shown in Fig. 18(b and c), NPC appeared with the same shape as ZIF-8 with the existence of nanopores, but they are not regularly ordered. on the other hand, NPN was found as nanoflakes with an observable space between particles that have a literal size of 100‒300 nm. This space can be helpful for facilitating the motion of ions and proceeding the electrochemical reaction. Interestingly, when the two electrodes were placed in a cell the operating potential was found 1.7 V as displayed in Fig. 18(d). The stored charge (Q) in asymmetrical devices is depended on specific capacitance (C), the applied potential (V), and the electrode mass (m) based on the equation of Q = C × V × m [120]. Whilst in the case of the charge-discharge curve, the picture is completely different, the ability to store the charge in the asymmetrical device should be similar from the ideal view. By taking into consideration this factor, the exact required weight from NPN and NPC was found to be 0.7 and 1 mg, consecutively. From the Ragone plot drawn in Fig. 18(f), the device could deliver the best efficiency of energy with 26 Wh/kg under the power density of 809 W/kg. It likewise still gives a good high energy density (14 Wh/kg) at high current (20 A/g) and 16,100 W/kg power density which is more improved compared to the previously reported for the symmetric device fabricated from NPC (10.86 Wh/kg) [121]. Nevertheless, the as-made asymmetrical device has shown big progress in the maximum specific energy compared to that of other formerly mentioned reports [122–125]. However, a shortcoming is noticed in the system where the achieved surface area of the faradic nickel oxide material was so low (78 m2/g) and should be increased in the future by discovering new porous redox structures with high surface area to raise the number of active sites that able to undergo the reaction and increase the obtained energy density of the cell. For the total investigation of the as-prepared device, long cycling of charge–discharge current was performed as shown in Fig. 15(g). As it can withstand up to 5000 cycles with unpretentious capacitance loss (2%). Table 2 summarizes mostly all the aforementioned electrochemical features for the utilization of PB or their derivatives as active materials for supercapacitors. Finally, pristine PB and PBA were observed to follow the pseudocapacitive behavior for charge transfer mechanisms showing a good capacitive property. Nevertheless, the various aforementioned works on their application as supercapacitors, there is still an imperative necessity for improving their weak points. Consequently, It can be concluded that these dilemmas could be overcome by several issues; (1) mixing with other new materials operated by the non-redox mechanism (ELDCs) and can be cycling stable such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and so on. (2) Increasing the specific surface area of their structure by controlling their synthesis approaches or by in situ decoration of these materials on porous 3D substrates. (3) The thermal heating of PB and PBA in an inert atmosphere can be used to produce nanoporous carbon decorated with metal nanoparticles which can be modified to metal oxides by the pyrolysis in the air to give supercapacitor electrodes with high electrochemical performance. (4) The potential to improve the capacitance can be further conducted by mixing PB or PBA with high conductive nanostructures of conducting polymers and metal derivatives such as oxides, sulphides, and phosphides. To this end, we can deduce that PB or PBA can be an excellent candidate for the fabrication of reliable active electrodes with fabulous features as supercapacitors. In addition to that, the outstanding properties of these materials can open the gate for being employed in various applications in the future. 7 Summary and outlook The new technologies for electricity generation have poverty to the utilization of energy storage devices such as supercapacitors which should be commercially used with a certain specification of capacitance, energy/power densities, and cycle life. Specifically, PB and their derivatives are known as one of the oldest and precious MOFs that can be used as electrode materials for supercapacitors because of their cost-effective, simple synthesis, high surface area, unrivaled open framework, excellent electrochemical features aside from their fast charge and discharge that coming from the outstanding structure. The present review is premier to overview up to date the research work achieved on PB and PBA for the field of supercapacitors, their different synthesis approaches. Besides, It exhibits various avenues for overcoming their disadvantages of bad cycle life, retention rate and not achieving the desired values of energy/power densities. The precise control of the PB or PBA features such as porosity, particle size, stability, and synthetic tunability could give a feasible base for obtaining specific bottlenecks in electrode activity to store the electrochemical energy. PB or PBA could be also hybridized with EDLCs materials such as graphene or with high conductive materials such as conducting polymer and metal derivatives as redox materials for improving their electrochemical behavior. PB or PBA can be transformed into other interesting nanostructures as they can be worked as sacrificial agents to prepare metal derivatives such as oxides, sulfides, and phosphides or bicomponent of graphitic carbon nitride/metal oxides with high cycle life and energy density. Despite the previous effort done on PB and PBA, there is still urgently need to search deeply on their influential application in the field of energy storage devices. As, the fabulous approaches that are conducted in polymers, carbon-based materials, inorganics, and ionic liquid can be considered as a good oracle for finding and exploring new nano architectures from PB or PBA with an eminent energy storage ability. Moreover, the research on figuring out new PB or PBA nanocomposite is still immensely deficient and under investigation. It can be deemed as a key point for occupying the intersection between PB and conventional material base electrodes. In the future, the collected data on PB and PBA based supercapacitors will be precious for engineering the next generation materials to be implemented in flexible electronics, sophisticated energy storage devices and solid-state electrolytes that can be worked in the extreme and mild conditions. Dr. Emad S. Goda received his B.S. degree in Chemistry from Monofiya University in 2010, and M.Sc degree in chemistry, Cairo University, Egypt in 2016. He is currently pursuing his Ph.D. from Hannam University, South Korea under Prof. Kuk Ro Yoon's supervision. He is also a researcher at the national institute of standards, Egypt. His-research interests focus on energy storage devices, antibacterial membranes, polymer nanocomposites, senors and biomedical applications including MOFs, PB, 3D graphene, hierarchical hybrids and conducting polymers. Dr. Muhammad Sohail is currently working as a researcher in the research and development department of Vinatech company limited, jaenju, South Korea. He got his Ph.D. degree in advanced energy and system engineering from Korea University of Science and Technology (UST), Daejeon, South Korea in 2020. His-recent research interests focus on the development of efficient electrochemical double layer capacitors.

coredata.dc:description: Remarkable attention has been directed to Prussian blue (PB) and its analogues (PBA) as one of the most widely used metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) especially in the field of energy storage devices due to their fabulous features such as 3D open framework, high surface area, controllable distribution of pores and the low cost. Nevertheless, their depressed conductivity causes some insulation when being used as an electrode for supercapacitors leading to be restricted in further applications particularly the electronics. To the best of our knowledge, our review aimed primarily to give a total picture of the research that was done on utilizing PB and PBA for fabricating the electrodes of supercapacitor, studying their synthesis approaches in addition to the hybridization with other materials such as graphene, CNTs and conducting polymer. It also addresses the transformation of PB or PBA into other interesting nanostructures such as oxides, sulfides, and bicomponent of graphitic carbon nitride/metal oxides, as well. Furthermore, It exhibits various avenues for overcoming their disadvantages of bad cycle life, retention rate and not achieving the desired values of energy/power densities opening the door for enlarging the number of researches on their application as supercapacitors.
